page_analysis.text_content:
Setbacks

Setbacks
apportion a
lot into two
parts:

• buildable area
(in the middle)

• required yards
(surrounding the
building area).

These required yards,
meant to be maintained
as open space areas, are
important as landscaping
opportunities to keep our
neighborhoods attractive
as well as for the preser-
vation of privacy.

Code sections
Page 20
18.12.040 (a) Table 2
18.12.040 (a,c,e,& i)
Page 21
18.04.040 (e)
Page 22–23
18.040.030 (84, 87, 91,
128, & 146)
Page 24–25
as shown in table

20

Standard setbacks apply in most
cases.

Special setbacks

Special setbacks override standard
setbacks unless a larger contextual
setback applies.

Streets w/special setbacks

Alma St
Arastradero Rd
Ash St
California Ave

Charleston Rd

Special setback distances can be found on:

• pages of the city's zone-map booklet (available both online
and in hardback at the Development Center)

• parcel reports from the city's GIS (available at the Develop-
ment Center)

* For front setback, if contextual setback is greater than 30'
then it applies—otherwise, the 20' setback applies.

* For front & street side setbacks a special setback may apply.
If both a contextual and special setback apply, the greater of
the two setbacks is required.

visual_elements.description: A simple diagram illustrating 'buildable area' and 'required yards'. It shows a rectangular shape (representing a lot) with a smaller, central rectangular shape labeled 'buildable area (in the middle)' and the surrounding area labeled 'required yards (surrounding the building area)'.

A table titled 'Standard setbacks by zone' with columns for 'Zone District', 'Front', 'Rear', 'Interior Side', and 'Street Side'. It lists various R-1 zone districts and their corresponding setback values, which can be 'Contextual or 20', numerical values, or 'see zone'/'na'.
visual_elements.location: Middle left, below 'Standard setbacks by zone' heading

visual_elements.description: A list of street names under the heading 'Streets w/special setbacks', organized into three columns.
visual_elements.location: Middle right, below 'Streets w/special setbacks' heading

subheadings: Standard setbacks apply in most cases.
Special setbacks override standard setbacks unless a larger contextual setback applies.
Special setback distances can be found on:

additional_notes: The page number '20' is present at the bottom left.
Asterisk symbols are used as footnotes for the table and for specific setback rules.
cross_references: city's zone-map booklet (available both online and in hardback at the Development Center)
parcel reports from the city's GIS (available at the Development Center)

qualifiers.text: If both a contextual and special setback apply

conditions.text: the greater of the two setbacks is required
conditions.threshold_value: greater of contextual and special setback

conditions.text: Special setbacks override standard setbacks unless a larger contextual setback applies.

logical_relationships.expression: IF (contextual setback is greater than 30') THEN (it applies) ELSE (the 20' setback applies)
For front & street side setbacks a special setback may apply.
If both a contextual and special setback apply, the greater of the two setbacks is required.
Special setbacks override standard setbacks unless a larger contextual setback applies.

execution_sequence.action: Determine if special setbacks override standard setbacks.
For front setback, evaluate contextual setback against 30'.
For front & street side setbacks, determine if a special setback applies.
If both contextual and special setbacks apply for front & street side, determine the greater value.
